artifact_name: oinochoe(possibly); stemmed bowl(possibly a stem or lid)
Object Type: stemmed bowl (possibly a stem or lid)
Description: Body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery vessel, possibly an oinochoe or stemmed bowl stem or lid; white slip; exterior, from top: billet pattern between bands; below, black-figure decoration consisting of siren to left (lower body and part of wing missing; added red on hair, wing, and chest); incised rosette with red centre as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group A of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The decoration on the vases from this group is the most elaborate. The rosette has a standard cogwheel shape and the figures are carefully drawn and details are expertly incised. Beazley suggests that the sherd may come from an aryballos but the shape is not known in Chian pottery. Lemos suggests that it might come from an oinochoe. Oinochoai are not common Chian shapes. If the sherd does come from an oinochoe, it would come from the shoulder area. If the sherd comes from a lid, then it likely formed part of the upper region of the lid near the handle. For a parallel regarding stemmed bowl stems, see Lemos no. 1272 from Pitane.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 320, no. 1426, pl. 185)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 41. pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2128) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
